[Vacancy] Post-doctoral researcher in computer science and artificial intelligence

The Asser Institute is seeking a post-doctoral researcher in computer science and artificial intelligence to join the NWO-funded interdisciplinary research project DILEMA on Designing International Law and Ethics into Military Artificial Intelligence. We kindly ask for your assistance in sharing this vacancy and spreading the word in your networks. The deadline for applications is 30 April 2021.

The Asser Institute invites applications for a post-doctoral researcher with a background in computer science, to conduct research on how to integrate legal norms and ethical values in the design of autonomous technologies, and how to implement monitoring and enforcement mechanisms that guarantee compliance with these norms and values.

Tasks
• Conduct fundamental and applied research within the DILEMA project;
• Publish articles in high-level academic journals;
• Develop and apply engineering methods on normative AI design and certification;
• Present research at academic conferences;
• Engage with project partners and relevant private and public stakeholders;
• Assist in the organization of research and dissemination activities within the DILEMA project;
• Work together with the other team members of the DILEMA project;
• Contribute actively to the Asser research community.

Requirements
• A completed PhD in computer science or artificial intelligence;
• Familiarity with both data-driven as well as knowledge-driven AI methods;
• A track-record of academic publications;
• A strong research interest in responsible innovation and governance of technologies;
• Experience or interest in interdisciplinary research;
• Ability to work both independently and as part of a team;
• Fluency in English.

Please visit our vacancy page to view application requirements and submission details. The deadline for applications is 30 April 2021.

Apply now

About the DILEMA project
The DILEMA project explores interdisciplinary perspectives on military applications of artificial intelligence (AI), with a focus on legal, ethical, and technical approaches on safeguarding human agency over military AI. It analyses in particular subtle ways in which AI can affect or reduce human agency, and seeks to ensure compliance with international law and accountability by design. More information about the project is available on the vacancy page and the project’s website.
